document.docAuthor: Padhye, Sameer M & Dumont, Henri J
document.masterDocTitle: Moina hemanti sp. nov., a new species of the genus Moina s. l. (Branchiopoda: Anomopoda) from Pune, India

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Moina hemanti sp. nov., a new species of the genus Moina s. l. (Branchiopoda: Anomopoda) from Pune, India

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The species is dedicated to Dr. Hemant Ghate, a well known zoologist from Pune, India who has studied a range of insects and has helped many Indian students in their entomological studies.

Type locality.
Moina hemanti
was seen only in one pool in the studied site, but consistently over three years (2010 – 2013). The diameter of the pool was about 90 cm . The depth was about 10 cm with no aquatic vegetation. The substrate consisted of mud with dead leaves fallen from the canopy. Its pH of ranged between 7–7.5 and temperature between 26–28°C.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype
A parthenogenetic female mounted on a glass slide in Polyvinyllactophenol ( PVLP ) (Registration number: C 6196/2). It has been submitted at Zoological Survery of India ( ZSI ) Kolkata.

Paratypes .
Ten parthenogenetic females (in 70% ethanol) have been deposited as paratypes (Registration number: C 6197/2) to ZSI . Nine parthenogenetic females and one male (in 5% formalin) have been deposited as paratypes to Wildlife Information Liaison Development society (Registration number: WILD-14-CRU-001)

subSubSection.paragraph: Collector for Holotype and paratype material: Dr. Yugandhar Shinde.

Diagnosis. Parthenogenetic female oval in shape with height/length ratio 0.6–0.74. Dorsal valve convex, valves striated. Rostrum slightly developed with varying rostral tip. Large ocellus present. Antenna 1 slender and lined with fine setae in groups on the posterior face; second antennae with two sensory setae of unequal length, small spine at base, projecting outwards. Abdomen with one protuberance. Postabdomen with 5–10 setulated teeth and asymmetric bident tooth, 4–5 basal spines on postabdominal claw.
Male with long antennule and 4 stout hooks at the tip. IDL of P1 with four setae, two long and setulated, two short and naked.

Description. Parthenogenetic female.
General. Body oval and with height/length ratio (0.60–0.74) ( Fig.1 : C, Fig.5 : A).

Head of small size, length less than 4 times the total body length ( Figs.1C , 2A , 5C ), supra-ocular depression present but not prominent ( Figs. 2A , 5C ). Rostrum well visible, its tip slightly upturned ( Figs. 2A ‘arrow’, 4C ‘star’) but few specimens had a straight tip with no curvature ( Fig. 1C ). Compound eye large ( Figs. 2A , 5C ), small ocellus located beneath the compound eye ( Figs. 1C , 2A ). No hairs present on the head ( Fig. 5C ).

Labrum . Main body with a slightly convex dorsal margin, basal segment roughly cylindrical in shape, apical segment tip quadrate in shape, slightly upturned (Daphnid type ,
Dumont et al . 2013
and references therein) and lined with setae gradually decreasing in size posteriorly. ( Fig. 2C ).

FIGURE 2 .
Moina hemanti
sp. nov .
from Pune, India. A, Head showing rostral tip (arrow). B, Postero-ventral margin (part) showing arrangement of various spines and spinules. C, Labrum. D, Antennule, E) Antenna. F, Basal sensory setae of Antenna. G, Setulation (part) of the basal seta of the endopod of Antenna. H, Postabdomen with the abdominal process (gray). I, Postabdomen. J–K, Variation in shape of Postabdomen. L, Bident tooth of Postabdomen. M, Posterior margin of the valve with setulated hook (gray) (Scale bars: A,B,C,D,F,G,I,J,K,L & M = 10 µm; E & H = 100 µm).

FIGURE 3.
Moina hemanti
sp. nov .
from Pune, India. A, P1 (seta in gray: Anterior seta of endite 3). B, Setulation (part) of the anterior seta of endite 3. C, P2. D, basal seta (gray) of exopodite of P2. E, P2 with endital setae. F, Gnathobase of P2 (1–4: inner setae; a–m: filtering setae; “star” – beating seta). G, Exopodite of P3. H, Exopodite of P4. I, P5. J, P1 of male (“arrow” showing IDL). K, P1 of male showing the 4 IDL setae. (Scale bars: A,C,E,G,H & I = 100 µm; B,D,F,J & K = 10 µm).

FIGURE 4.
Moina hemanti
sp. nov .
from Pune, India. A, Male head (part) with Antennule. B, Antenna I tip showing hooks. C, Postabdomen (part) showing the gonopore. (Scale bars: A = 100 µm; B & C = 10 µm).

subSubSection.paragraph: Antennule slender, cylindrical, lined with setules on the posterior face and short spinules on the anterior face. Sensory seta located closer to base than to mid length and slightly more in length than the antennule base. Nine aesthetascs located at the tip Fig. 2D ).

Antenna long, two setae located at the base of unequal length ( Fig. 2F ) with length slightly more than the length of coxal segment. Long sensory seta, attached to the base ( Fig. 2E ), extending up to middle of the third antennal segment. Basal segment with a short spine projecting outwards ( Figs. 2E , 5B “arrow”) Antennal setal formula: 0-0-1-3/1-1-3 and spines formula: 0-1-0-1/0-0-1. Each segment lined with transverse rows of small spinules ( Fig. 5B ) with plumose setulation; lateral seta of basal segment of endopod asymmetrically setulated with one side having long plumose setulation while the other side having very short setules ( Fig.2 : G).
Abdomen with a small single abdominal projection ( Fig. 2H shaded gray).

Postabdomen well extended and narrowing distally ( Figs. 2I , 5E ); ventral margin straight but slightly variable ( Figs.2J & K ) and with slightly convex border. Margin lined with rows of setules. Six-ten triangular plumose teeth laterally ( Figs. 2I , 5E ). Bident tooth with highly unequal branches, ( Figs. 2L , 5D ‘arrow’) with distal tooth at least twice as long as proximal tooth and first few plumose denticles. A fine row of spinules present anterior to the plumose teeth ( Fig. 5 D ). Large postabdominal claw, bowed and with an acute and projecting apex, lined with fine pecten dorsally ( Fig. 5D ). Usually four robust basal spines present at the proximal end of the claw ( Figs. 2I , 5D ); 5 spines also seen but 3 spines not observed. Ventral margin at the base of claw also lined with 3–6 stout denticles ( Fig.5 : D ‘star’).

Limb 1 with 10 setae, ejector hooks well developed, unequal in size ( Fig. 3A ). IDL with 3 setae, the anterior most with fine setulation. Endite 3 with two setae, one relatively short anterior seta slightly more chitinized, curved and lined with undersized setulation ( Figs. 3A shaded gray, 3B, 5C ‘arrow’) and one posterior seta with long setules. Endite 2 with 2 long setae and endite 1 with 3 setae and plumose setulation ( Fig. 3A ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Moina hemanti
sp. nov .
from Pune, India. A, Habitus. B, Antennule. C, Head (“arrow” showing the anterior seta of endite 3). D, Postabdominal claw. E, Postabdomen and sculpturing of the valve.

subSubSection.paragraph: Limb 3 . Exopodite sub-rectangular with 6 setae, bilaterally setulated, setal length: 3>4>6>1~5>2 ( Fig.3G ). Four endital setae and 38–42 gnathobasic filter setae present.
Limb 4 . Exopodite rounded with 6 setae, bilaterally setulated, setal lengths similar to exopodite of limb3 ( Fig.3 : H).Two endital setae and 30–34 gnathobasic filtering setae present.

Limb 5 . Exopodite with 2 setae, highly unequal size, longer seta at least 1.2 times the length of the exopodite body. Endopod with ovoid lobe and 2 setae, one nearly as long as the 1st exopodite seta, 2nd seta 1/3rd of the length of the first. All setae bilaterally setulated ( Fig.3 : I).

Ephippial female .
In spite of intensive search, we were not able to find any sexual females or ephippia either.
Size. Females ranging from 640 to 850 µm (n=15). Males ranging from 510 to 620 µm (n=5).

Distribution and ecology : Known only from type locality. It was found in a stream-fed ephemeral pool. The pool was extremely labile with regards to its duration. It used to get turbid in few days (with distinct pungent smell) if the rains stopped and became dry soon after, suggesting little Dissolved Oxygen. Therefore, all animals collected were characteristically red in color ( Fig.1C ). The pool was visited by cattle regularly and hence dispersal via these carriers would be likely but no specimens were seen in any other pools that formed in that habitat nor in any localities nearby.
